comment_text: Have a read of the book 'The Brendan Voyage' by Tim Severin. It retraces the trip made by an Irish monk in the early 500's, in a replica, leather clad, coracle. When they got to the Faroes they found a lot of large sheep and met an inhabitant who provided them with food for the journey. So there were residents there before the 500's, long before the Vikings arrived.

Just a friendly reminder: “Faroe Islands” is redundant. Faroe literally means sheep islands. So saying Faroe Islands is saying Sheep Islands Islands. You should just say Faroes and leave it at that. I know a Faroese person, so this is straight from the source. Also, Norse settlers and explorers are not the same as vikings. Viking is a verb meaning to go raid and pillage. Those who went Viking were vikingers or vikingrs. Norse people out for a friendly sail with their sheep and barley grains were not Viking, they were just traveling. Some of them may have participated in Viking at some point, but at the time they were moving their homes to a new island, they weren’t.

Unless I'm missing something, this doesn't tell us that humans lived on the Faroe Islands. It tells us that sheep lived there. And it's pretty common for people to introduce species to islands without predators, and then leave them to reproduce. Only visiting once or twice a year to shear the sheep and maybe grab some lambs.

Please don't conflate Norse peoples with Vikings. There is overlap between these two groups, of course, but the majority of the agrarian settlers on the Faroes were Very Likely not Vikings. The Víkingr were raiders of usually Scandinavian origin, but "Viking" is much closer to a job description (or subculture?) than a Culture. Calling the early Faroese "Vikings" was probably done intentionally as shorthand for the audience's sake, but it's inaccurate and feeds into some unfortunate misconceptions about early Norse peoples.

How weird and fascinating that petrified (fossilized?) sheep poop was the key to establishing habitation. Scientist to friend, "You're never going to believe this Joe, we got sheep poop in here from 1,500 years ago."  2nd scientist, "Whoo hooo, we're gonna be famous!  Sheep poop is gonna change the accepted historical record."  Both scientists, dancing round and round, "Sheep poop, wonderful wonderful sheep poop,"
